Description: Body sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black with two added white bands; exterior: painted decoration consisting of sphinx standing to right (rump, chest and part of wing remaining).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Lemos, sphinxes on Chalice Style vases are usually facing left. It is quite possible that a sphinx facing right may be part of an antithetical composition, and so if this sherd is part of an antithetical composition, then the vessel should perforce belong in the Group of Antithetical Sphinxes. Pots in this group are both stylistically and chronologically early. The fabric of the sherd was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Using Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA), it was found that the fabric originated in the Kampos plain in the east of the island of Chios (Jones with J.Boardman in Jones 1986, p.286).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 292, no. 902, pl. 121)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 81, no. 9, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1221) (phase 2)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.285, table 3.21, no.9)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
